sen.j: カヤナルミとは、『延喜式』「祝詞式」にある『出雲国造神賀詞』では賀夜奈流美、飛鳥坐神社・加夜奈留美命神社では加夜奈留美とされている女神。
sen.e: Kayanarumi is a female deity referred as 賀夜奈流美 in "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" (ritual greetings of Izumo kokuso, the high priest of Izumo Taisha Shrine) in "Norito shiki" of "Engishiki" (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers); or 加夜奈留美 at Asukani Imasu-jinja Shrine and Kayanarumi-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 『出雲国造神賀詞』には「賀夜奈流美命乃御魂乎飛鳥乃神奈備尓坐天皇孫命能近守神登貢置天」とあり、「大物主櫛長瓦玉命」、「阿遅須伎高孫根乃命」（アヂスキタカヒコネ）、事代主とともに天皇家を守護する神として述べられている。
sen.e: "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" reads "Kayanarumi no mikoto no mitama wo asuka no kamunabi ni masete, sumemimano mikoto no chikaki mamori no kami to tatematsuri okite."

sen.j: が、古事記の大国主の系図に登場する鳥鳴海神（トリナルミ）や布忍富鳥鳴海神（ヌノシトミトリナルミ）（どちらも男神）との関連が考えられる。
sen.e: Still, it is believed that Kayanarumi is related to Torinarumi or Nunoshitomitorinarumi (both are male deities) that are mentioned in the genealogy of Okuninushi described in "Kojiki."

sen.j: ただし『日本書紀』第6の一書には「事代主神化爲八尋熊鰐 通三嶋溝樴姫 或云 玉櫛姫 而生兒姫蹈鞴五十鈴姫命 是爲神日本磐余彦火火出見天皇之后也」との記述がある。
sen.e: In the sixth alternate writing in "Nihonshoki" reads "Kotoshironushi no kami transformed into Yahiro no Kumawani to marry to Mishima no Mizokuihime, or also called Tamakushihime, and the child was born named Himetataraisuzuhimenomikoto, who became the wife of Kamuyamatoiwarehiko Hohodemino sumeramikoto."

sen.e: However, according to the sixth addendum to the "Nihonshoki," "Kotoshironushi no kami transformed into Yahiro no Kumawani to marry Mishima no Mizokuihime, also called Tamakushihime, and the child was born named Himetataraisuzuhimenomikoto, who became the wife of Kamuyamatoiwarehiko Hohodemino sumeramikoto."

However, according to the sixth addendum to the "Nihonshoki," 'Kotoshironushi no kami transformed into Yahiro no Kumawani to marry Mishima no Mizokuihime, also called Tamakushihime, and the child was born named Himetataraisuzuhimenomikoto, who became the wife of Kamuyamatoiwarehiko Hohodemino sumeramikoto.'

sen.j: 『旧事本紀』では「都味歯八重事代主神 化爲八尋熊鰐通三嶋溝杭女活玉依姫 生一男一女（略）」とあり事代主神が八尋鰐と化したことの記述がある。
sen.e: "Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) reads "Tsumihayae kotoshironushinokami transformed into Yahirokumawani to marry to the daughter of Mishima no Mizokuihime, Ikutamayorihime and had a boy and a girl," indicating Kotoshironushinokami transformed into Yahirowani.
